name: The Ani-Yun'wiya Spirits
description: The spiritual world of the Cherokee — the Ani-Yun'wiya, the Principal People — as recorded primarily by James Mooney in Myths of the Cherokee (1900), drawn from years of work with the Eastern Band in the Qualla Boundary of western North Carolina. Mooney's primary informant was Swimmer (Ayunini), a medicine man who carried an extraordinary body of sacred formulas and narratives. The Cherokee cosmos operates on a principle of radical balance: disease exists because the animals, offended by careless hunters, sent illnesses to punish humanity, and plants — taking pity on the people — offered themselves as cures. Every sickness has a plant remedy. Every act has a consequence. Every power has a counter-power. The world is layered — an upper world of order and structure, a lower world of chaos and inversion, and this middle world where humans navigate between them. What makes the Cherokee system psychologically distinctive is its insistence that balance is not a static state but a constant negotiation, maintained through formula, ceremony, and attention to the reciprocal obligations that bind every living thing to every other.

deities.name: Selu
deities.title: The Corn Mother
deities.description: Selu is the first woman, wife of Kanati the hunter, and the origin of corn — and the way corn comes into the world is the story's unforgettable center. As recorded by Mooney from Swimmer's telling, Selu's two sons — the wild boy and the tame boy — spy on her and discover her secret: she produces corn by rubbing her stomach or armpits over a basket, the grain falling from her own body. Disgusted, the boys decide she is a witch and resolve to kill her. Selu, knowing what they intend, does not resist. She instructs them: after they kill her, they must drag her body seven times around a cleared piece of ground, and corn will grow where her blood touches the earth. The boys, being boys, drag her body only twice (or in some versions clear only part of the ground), which is why corn does not grow everywhere and must be cultivated with labor. This is a sacrifice narrative of extraordinary compression. The food that sustains the people comes from the body of a woman who was killed by her own children because they could not tolerate the mystery of where sustenance came from. The killing is not divine punishment or tragic accident — it is the cost of knowledge. Once the boys see the source, they cannot unknow it, and the source must die for the knowledge to become food. Jack Frederick Kilpatrick and Anna Gritts Kilpatrick's later work with Oklahoma Cherokee communities confirmed that Selu's story remained central to Cherokee identity well into the twentieth century. Psychologically, the pattern resonates with any creative process: the thing you make comes from your own substance, and the people who consume it rarely want to know what it cost.

deities.name: Kanati
deities.title: The Lucky Hunter
deities.description: Kanati is the first man, Selu's husband, called the Lucky Hunter because he never failed to bring home game. In Mooney's recording of Swimmer's account, the two boys follow Kanati into the mountains and discover his secret: he keeps all the game animals sealed inside a cave, blocked by a great rock. When he wants to hunt, he opens the rock slightly, lets one animal out, and kills it. The boys, impatient, roll the stone away entirely, and all the animals escape into the world at once — deer, bear, turkey, every creature — scattering in all directions, never again to be so easily obtained. This is the Cherokee parallel to Pandora's box or the Fall, but with a critical difference: the disaster is not about disobedience to a divine command but about the destruction of a managed system by people who wanted the reward without understanding the structure. Kanati's hunting was successful because it was controlled — one animal at a time, taken with precision. The boys wanted abundance without constraint, and the result was scarcity. Mooney noted that the Kanati-Selu cycle functions as a paired origin story: the man's secret (the cave of game) and the woman's secret (the body that produces corn) are both discovered and destroyed by the next generation, and from that destruction comes the actual world — a world where hunting requires skill and corn requires labor. The Cherokee did not tell a story about paradise lost to sin. They told a story about a managed system disrupted by immaturity, and the result is not punishment but work. The Kilpatricks documented variants where Kanati eventually teaches the boys proper hunting formulas, restoring partial balance — not the original ease, but a sustainable relationship with the animals, maintained through ritual and respect.

deities.name: Ani-Hyuntikwalaski
deities.title: The Thunder Beings
deities.description: The Ani-Hyuntikwalaski — the Thunderers — are among the most powerful beings in the Cherokee upper world. Mooney recorded multiple accounts from Swimmer and other informants describing them as great beings who live in the sky, whose voices are thunder and whose weapons are lightning. They are not weather phenomena given narrative clothing; in Cherokee understanding, they are persons with agency and intention, and their primary function is protective. The Thunderers wage constant war against the forces of the lower world — particularly the great serpents and water monsters that threaten human communities. When lightning strikes the ground, it is often understood as a Thunder Being attacking an Uktena or other dangerous creature. The Cherokee formula tradition, documented extensively by Mooney and later by the Kilpatricks from the Swimmer manuscript and other sacred texts, includes prayers addressed to the Thunder Beings for protection, for success in war, and for the curing of certain diseases. The relationship is reciprocal: the Thunderers are addressed with respect, offered tobacco, and acknowledged as allies rather than commanded as servants. Their position in the upper world — the realm of order, structure, and clarity — places them in opposition to the chaotic forces of the under world, and the middle world where humans live is the contested territory between these two domains. Psychologically, the Thunderers represent the principle that order must be actively defended. Balance is not automatic. Something must fight for it, and the fight is ongoing, audible in every summer storm that rolls through the Smoky Mountains.

deities.name: Asgaya Galunlati
deities.title: The Thunder Man Above
deities.description: Asgaya Galunlati — literally 'the Man in the Sky' or 'the Man Above' — appears in Cherokee sacred formulas as a supreme or near-supreme figure invoked in the most powerful prayers and curing ceremonies. Mooney encountered the name throughout the sacred formula manuscripts he collected from Swimmer, and it functions differently from the Thunder Beings as a collective: Asgaya Galunlati is singular, addressed directly in formulas for the most serious purposes — curing life-threatening illness, ensuring success in critical undertakings, seeking the highest available intervention. The Kilpatricks, working with Cherokee medicine practitioners in Oklahoma decades later, confirmed that Asgaya Galunlati remained a figure of central importance in the formula tradition. Some scholars have debated whether this figure represents a pre-contact Cherokee concept of a supreme deity or whether contact with Christian missionaries inflected an existing Thunder deity upward into a more monotheistic frame. The honest answer is that the evidence is ambiguous. What is clear from the formulas themselves is that Asgaya Galunlati is addressed as the most powerful available ally — invoked when lesser spirits are insufficient, when the stakes are survival. The formulas addressing him follow precise ritual language, use specific color symbolism (red for success, black for death, white for peace, blue for defeat), and are not casual prayers but carefully structured invocations. Cherokee medicine men memorized hundreds of these formulas, each calibrated to a specific purpose, and the ones addressed to Asgaya Galunlati were reserved for the gravest circumstances. This is not a god who governs daily life but one who is called when the ordinary systems of balance have failed and extraordinary intervention is required.

deities.name: Long Man
deities.title: The River Spirit
deities.description: Long Man — Yunwi Gunahi'ta, the 'Long Human Being' — is the river itself understood as a person: his head lies in the mountains where the water springs from the earth, and his feet extend far downstream to where the river empties into larger waters. Mooney recorded that the Cherokee regarded rivers as living beings with consciousness and will, and Long Man was the most important of these — a being whose voice could be heard by those who knew how to listen, speaking from the sound of the current over rocks. Cherokee purification ceremonies, particularly the ritual of 'going to water' (ama diyohi), required immersion in running water — the river, not standing water — because Long Man's flowing body carried away impurity. Swimmer's formulas include specific prayers spoken while facing upstream, addressing Long Man directly, asking him to wash away disease, grief, or spiritual contamination. The practice was not symbolic: the person entered the water at dawn, faced east, recited the formula, and immersed. The Kilpatricks documented that 'going to water' persisted among Oklahoma Cherokee communities as a living practice, not a relic. Psychologically, the identification of a river as a person whose body you enter for healing is remarkable. It is not baptism in the Christian sense — there is no sin being washed away, no salvation being conferred. It is a relationship with a specific being who has the power to carry things downstream, to move what is stuck, to dissolve what has accumulated. Long Man is movement itself — the insistence that health requires flow, that stagnation is the condition illness exploits.

deities.name: Uktena
deities.title: The Great Horned Serpent
deities.description: The Uktena is the most dangerous creature in Cherokee mythology — a great serpent as large as a tree trunk, covered in scales that flash like sparks of fire, with antlers like a deer and a single blazing crystal (the Ulun'suti) embedded in its forehead. Mooney's account, drawn from Swimmer and other Eastern Band informants, describes the Uktena as a being of the under world — the realm of chaos, inversion, and power without order — whose gaze alone could kill. To see the Uktena was nearly always fatal. But the crystal on its forehead, if a hunter could obtain it, was the most powerful talisman in Cherokee medicine: the Ulun'suti granted its possessor the ability to see the future, ensure success in hunting, attract love, and cure disease. The catch — and there is always a catch in Cherokee narrative — is that the crystal had to be fed with blood, specifically the blood of game animals, or it would kill its owner. Power, in the Cherokee system, is never free and never safe. It always requires maintenance, always demands a cost, always carries the risk of destroying the person who wields it. The story of Aganunitsi (the Groundhog's Mother), who succeeded in killing an Uktena and obtaining the crystal, is one of the great quest narratives in Cherokee tradition: he succeeded not through strength but through preparation, following precise ritual instructions, and even then barely survived. The Uktena represents the under-world principle that the most potent power is also the most lethal, and that the boundary between medicine and poison is a matter of dosage and discipline. Cherokee ethnobotany, documented in detail by researchers working with traditional plant knowledge, reflects this same principle: many of the most effective medicinal plants are also toxic in improper doses.

deities.name: Tlanuwa
deities.title: The Great Mythic Hawk
deities.description: The Tlanuwa are giant hawks — predatory birds of immense size and ferocity that nested in the high cliffs of the southern Appalachians. Mooney recorded from his Cherokee informants that the Tlanuwa were powerful enough to carry off large game and even children, and their nesting sites were associated with specific cliff faces in the mountains of western North Carolina and eastern Tennessee. The Tlanuwa exist in perpetual enmity with the great serpents of the under world, particularly the Uktena, and the stories describe aerial battles between the hawks and the horned serpents — upper-world power against under-world power, the sky predator against the water monster. In one account recorded by Mooney, a Tlanuwa seized a great serpent and dropped it on the rocks below, and the serpent's blood stained the stone permanently. This upper-world/under-world warfare is a structural feature of Cherokee cosmology: the two realms are in constant tension, and the middle world — where humans live — is shaped by their conflict. The Tlanuwa are not friendly to humans. They are allies in the sense that they oppose the serpents, but they are not tame, not domesticated, not safe. They are the raptor principle at its most extreme: vision from height, speed, killing precision, and complete indifference to anything that is not prey or enemy. Archaeologist Jan Simek and collaborators have documented Mississippian-era cave art in Tennessee depicting Tlanuwa-like figures, suggesting the tradition extends well before European contact into the broader Southeastern Ceremonial Complex. The Tlanuwa are the Cherokee reminder that the forces that protect you from below are not necessarily concerned with your welfare — they fight the serpents for their own reasons, and you benefit incidentally.

deities.name: Nunnehi
deities.title: The Immortals
deities.description: The Nunnehi — the 'People Who Live Anywhere' or the Immortals — are invisible spirit people who inhabit the mountains, particularly the high balds and remote peaks of the southern Appalachians. Mooney collected extensive accounts from Eastern Band Cherokee who described the Nunnehi as a parallel people: they live in townhouses inside the mountains, they dance, they feast, they have their own social life, and they are generally well-disposed toward the Cherokee, occasionally appearing to warn of danger or to aid in battle. During the removal crisis of the 1830s — the Trail of Tears — Mooney recorded that some Cherokee believed the Nunnehi had offered to take people into their mountain dwelling places to escape the forced march. Certain Cherokee who disappeared during the chaos of removal were said to have gone to live with the Nunnehi rather than die on the trail. The psychological function of the Nunnehi is layered: they represent the possibility that the mountains themselves are inhabited by benevolent intelligence, that the land is not empty wilderness but a populated landscape with communities you cannot see. They also represent the possibility of escape — that somewhere inside the physical landscape there exists a version of Cherokee life untouched by colonial destruction. This is not escapism in the pejorative sense. When your nation is being forcibly marched a thousand miles from its homeland, the belief that some version of your people persists inside the mountains you are leaving is an act of spiritual resistance. The Nunnehi are the Cherokee insistence that the land remembers, even when the people are driven from it.

deities.name: Yunwi Tsunsdi
deities.title: The Little People
deities.description: The Yunwi Tsunsdi — the Little People — are small spirit beings, about knee-high to an adult, who live in the mountain caves, rock shelters, and laurel thickets of Cherokee territory. Mooney recorded multiple accounts distinguishing different types: the Laurel People, the Rock People, and the Dogwood People, each with different temperaments and functions. Some are helpful — they find lost children and guide them home. Some are mischievous — they move objects, create confusion, lead travelers astray. Some are dangerous if disrespected. The common rule, preserved across multiple informants, is that you must never tell anyone if you encounter the Little People, or at minimum you must wait seven days before speaking of it; breaking this rule brings illness or death. The Kilpatricks confirmed that belief in the Little People remained vigorous among Oklahoma Cherokee communities, not as quaint folklore but as an active element of how people understood their relationship to the landscape. Children were taught about the Yunwi Tsunsdi as both comfort and caution: someone is watching out for you in the woods, but the woods also contain beings whose rules are not your rules. Psychologically, the Little People occupy a space between the fully sacred and the domestic — they are not as powerful as the Thunder Beings or as dangerous as the Uktena, but they are present, immediate, and responsive to human behavior. They enforce a kind of ambient ethics: be respectful in the woods, do not take more than you need, do not speak carelessly about what you have seen. The landscape is not inert. It is populated, attentive, and it has opinions about your conduct.

deities.name: Water Spider
deities.title: The Fire Bringer
deities.description: The Water Spider — Kanane'ski Amai'yehi — is the being who brought fire to the animals and, through them, to the people, and her story is a study in what actually works when every impressive attempt fails. In Mooney's recording, after Thunderer placed fire in the base of a hollow sycamore tree on an island, every animal wanted to retrieve it. The great ones went first. Raven flew to the island, but the heat scorched his feathers black (which is why ravens are black). The screech owl tried and the smoke nearly blinded him (which is why his eyes are ringed with red). The black racer snake swam across, but the fire burned his skin and he has been black ever since. The great black snake tried and was likewise scorched. Each attempt by a large, powerful, or confident animal failed, and each failure left a permanent mark. Then the Water Spider volunteered — small, unimpressive, dismissed by the others. She spun a small bowl of her web, fastened it to her back, crossed the water, placed a single coal in the bowl, and brought fire back. No drama, no scorching, no permanent disfigurement. The smallest being succeeded because she had the right tool — a container she made from her own body — and the temperament to execute without spectacle. The story echoes across cultures (Prometheus, Maui, the African trickster traditions), but the Cherokee version is distinctive in its emphasis on pragmatism over heroism. The Water Spider is not celebrated for bravery or defiance. She is celebrated for competence. She built the right container, crossed the water without fanfare, and returned with what was needed. In a tradition that consistently values practical intelligence over dramatic gesture, the Water Spider is the model.

deities.name: Agan-unitsi
deities.title: The Groundhog's Mother
deities.description: Agan-unitsi — sometimes rendered as Aganunitsi, 'the Groundhog's Mother' — is the great hunter who succeeded in killing an Uktena and obtaining the Ulun'suti, the blazing crystal from the serpent's forehead. Mooney's account, drawn from Swimmer, describes a quest that multiple warriors attempted and failed, dying from the Uktena's gaze or its venomous breath before they could strike. Agan-unitsi succeeded through meticulous preparation: he dug a circular trench around a ridge where the Uktena was known to pass, lined it with pine logs, and positioned himself uphill. When the great serpent came, he shot it with an arrow, and it rolled downhill into the trench, thrashing in its death agony. The pine logs caught fire from the sparks thrown by its scales, and the creature was consumed, but the crystal — the Ulun'suti — rolled free from its forehead and landed in the blood. Agan-unitsi waited seven days (the ceremonially significant number in Cherokee tradition) before retrieving it, wrapping it in deerskin and keeping it fed with blood from game animals as the formulas prescribed. The story is a Cherokee quest narrative in the classical mold: the prize is real, the danger is lethal, and success depends not on courage alone but on knowledge of the correct procedure. Agan-unitsi did not overpower the Uktena — he engineered its destruction through terrain and preparation. The Ulun'suti itself is a concentrated image of the Cherokee relationship to power: it works, it grants real advantages, and it will kill you if you fail to maintain the relationship it demands. Power is not a possession. It is an obligation.

deities.name: U'tlunta
deities.title: Spearfinger
deities.description: U'tlunta — Spearfinger — is one of the most terrifying figures in Cherokee oral tradition: an old woman whose skin was made of stone, impervious to weapons, with a single long, sharp finger on her right hand shaped like an awl or obsidian blade. Mooney recorded from his Eastern Band informants that Spearfinger could take any form she chose, often appearing as a kindly grandmother to lure children close, and then she would stab her stone finger through their side and consume their liver, which was her sole food. Her skin could not be pierced by arrows or cut by knives; she was effectively invulnerable. The Cherokee defeated her only through intelligence: they dug a pit trap, lured her in, and then a chickadee — the tsi'kilili, a bird the Cherokee regarded as a truth-teller — landed on her hand and revealed that her heart was not in her chest but in her hand, the hand with the stone finger. They struck there, and she died. The structural logic is precise: the monster's weapon and her vulnerability are in the same place. Her power and her mortality share an address. Spearfinger is the predator who disguises herself as the caretaker — a figure with obvious psychological resonance for anyone who has encountered a person whose apparent nurture conceals consumption. She is also the embodiment of the Cherokee stone-skin motif: beings of the under world whose armor makes them nearly invincible, requiring not greater force but better knowledge to defeat. The chickadee's role — tiny, easily overlooked, but carrying the critical information — echoes the Water Spider pattern: in Cherokee narrative, the smallest being often holds the decisive intelligence.
